The Revised Edition



This book is dedicated to those who seek to add organization to the problem-solving process we

call life. It is for those who desire to take charge of the multitude of situations which confront them and for those who plan to assure themselves of achieving personally and socially satisfying ends.

In our few years of leading and participating in seminars and workshops involving creative problem solving, we, along with our colleagues and students, have come to appreciate the value of having the necessary tools and diagrams for proceeding on the problem-solving life journey. These pages represent the composite of notes gathered during such sessions, of our research and experimentation and of the comment and criticism found in feedback to earlier versions. We continue to welcome your responses

toward making this book more useful in future editions.

DON KOBERG and JIM BAGNALL

California Polytechnic State University

School of Architecture and Envirionmental Design San Luis Obispo, California, 93407


DON KOBERG is a teacher and architect who continues to search for life's common denominators.

JIM BAGNALL is a teacher & and graphic coordinator. He sees his role as that of visually simplifying the the complexities in life.

‌The goal of THE UNIVERSAL TRAVELER is to translate what began as a simple organizational realization and grew to become a highly specialized, computer assisted mathenatica and statistical discipline for solving complex world problems, back into an easy-to-learn language for everyday use. We believe that all problems, no matter what size they may be, can benefit from the same logical and orderly process na,..i employed to solve many of the complex problems of our time. The principles remain constant. It is only the methods which change, and then, often in appearance alone.

Since "Systems'.'is the name which has been assigned to Cybernetics and the various numerical techniques for modeling problem situations, we hi3-ve similarly called our more conversational approach by the name Soft-Systems. We hope the language of the Soft-Systems we have developed and translated in this book will help every reaqer_dea! more logical y and systematically with the situations which define the contextof their daily life...or in

th least to be able to deal" with them in a more creative way.

How the Universal Traveler


Â·,, Although we expect it to be self-evident, here I i the way in which THE UNIVERSAL TRAVELER has Deen designed to work for you:

';:'hroughout you will find continual references to the process of design as a journey or excursion. Tr.is symbolic "travel-ese" is used in order to reinforce the concept that design is rrore rreaningful when it can be visualized and pursued as a logical, planned journey through a series of ENERGY STATES and not Sllf4)ly taken as a random,chance process.

Before beginning any serious journey, it is well to stop at 1HE EXPEDITION OUfFI'ITER, where general advice and information is available for the kinds of tools and equipment you may require for the trip. The "OUI'FITTER" can also provide TRAVEL TIPS or hints, LANGUAGE GUIDES or notes on the semantics of. foreign tongues, and GUIDEBOOKS and additional refer nces, including a TRAVEL MAP.

'I"ne central part of the book is named THE 'Jl'IIVEF.SAL TRAVEL AGENCY because it is the information storehouse for journeys of all kinds. In it you will find the rretri.ods for getting started and for proceeding=along tooard the variol.!S points on your itinerary. r-;uch

‌seven major'phases.or-ENERGY STATES so that the.traveler might take a sample problem through the process in an efficient manner.

The final part of THE UNIVERSAL TRAVELER is called SIDE TRIPS. It contains some information which can enhance or enrich each journey and make it more Jreaningful. SIDE TRIPS are like bonuses for extra effort in problem-solving.

All travel guides are forever in need of updating, so THE UNIVERSAL TRAVELER has been printed with a wide margin on each page to provide plenty of room for your notes. As you discover methods of your own and adapt them to better meet your personal needs, it would be helpful to you to write them down on these pages. Th7DESIGN PROC SS is a sequence of events which demands creative behavior from its i<?ipants.. ts activity is to improve

ex:i.sting conditions and to tincl clear paths out of dilema.s. â¢

Creativity can be defined as both the art

  • and the science of thinking and behaving with subjectivity and objectivity. It is a

co ination of feeling and knowing; of alterÂ­ nating back and forth between what we sense and what we already know. Creativity may tend to make us abnorrral...to move us toward a state of wholeness which differs fran the priJilarily o jective or subjective person which typifies our society. For exarrple: The primarily objective person, being a knower

.,

after the fact, senses the natural and manÂ­ made envirorurent which surrounds him and then determines the existence of logic and beauty within that experience. The primarily subÂ­ jective person, being a here-and-now sense rrechanism, proceeds as a continuum of senso response, delighting in his experience,caring little for knowing. To combine the two is to gainrrore than both: a freedom from the

overall control of either one. Such I creatiâ¢ ve I

wholeness allows us to walk ahead of O\:Ir'Â­ selves...to both lead our way and to follow that way: to both determine our goal and to go:to both determine the resIX?nse and t establish the stimulus. And since that is obviously the activity of design,it se equally requisite for those who en e 1.n design to also work toward developing rrore creative behavior patterns.

Although sometimes necessary, problem solutions which rrerely 'work' and last for a tiJre do not represent what we can refer to

8



‌J, I

as,.c:reative solutions'. Creative problemÂ­ solutions are those which lead, which inspire, which provoke; those which he],.p us to imagine rrore advanced problems or which provide us with the rrodels for solving other, similar problems and which generally turn others on to their corTectness, obviousness or to their

simplicity. Designers (creative problem-solvers)

therefore, being persons who intend to go beyond rrereÂ·functi.on and stability, have occuÂ­ pational needs for developing certain behav- ioral attributes for creativity.

It is sinple enough to list those "attributes of creativity" which are needed by the designer and to point out the reasons for their incluÂ­ sion. But actual development and refine-

ment of such behavioral characteristics is

difficult since society makes it a relentless battle, an often thankless and rarely posiÂ­ tively reinforced chore to maintain such behavior.

The sane society which readily accepts the creative 'product' will chastise or deny the creative 'activity' required for such producÂ­ tion because of its non-typical nature.

The typically 11 abnormal" behavior of the cre!=ltive person may be described by normal society as boorish, prideless, maladjusted, carelessÂ·, even unpatriotic and a rrenace to the 'institutions' which 'average man' builds to perpetuate his 'average' or 'normal' behavior. Schools, operated by the perÂ­ petuation of "average" and administrationÂ­ oriented persons, punish all hints of 'wholeÂ­ ness' behavior. And although we say that we expect our schools to engender creativity, we.usually also alla,; a continuation of the discipline-over-developrrent approach to discouraging creative growth in our young.

When the human product emerges as a nonÂ­

creative, average sample, we do not complain; instead we alter the rreaning of creativity to describe other human abnorrra.lcy activities such as condoning high productivity as a creative act. So, in a very special sense, the creative person is abnormal: different from the others and therefore subject to their disapproval and discouragement.


Designers take note!! If your human relations are on a srrooth course, it is probable that one of two altematives is

in effect: either you are not being creative or you have conditioned yourseJÂ£ and the others in your environrrent to accept your abnormal behaviorÂ·.

Self-discipline, or.as Bobby Seale defines it, "behaving the same",is another way to say "freedom from pride11â¢ Pride is used here as a general tenn for the hangups associated with a lack of self-discipline. To be able to hold your head up high with prid is counter-creative behavior. To be concerned about sha.me is equally alien; both are traits which detract from the positive attainment of goals. Thus, pride stands in the way of creativity by inhibiting us from asking key questions, thus stifling the key requisite for curiosity. It restricts a change of mind or direction which thereby

10

fixes a preconceived and prejudicial course. And it runs counter to the true hwnility required for the 'giving' of oneself to the task! Pride sets up a condition of being untrue to one's self. By establishing a nonÂ­ constructive goal, pride (along with the other six "deadly sins" - greed, lust, sloth, envy, gluttony and hate - Thomas Aquinas) diverts. our attention from improvement.

Cbntrary to pride, self-discipline is a truth-reality behavior. "Behaving the sane11 requires the CO\..IZ'c3ge of convictions, the intention to understand and to cope with the problems of others, and the freedom from fear of social reprisal. It is a fearless acceptance of the responsibility of being what we are,knowing what we know and do not

know and of taking the steps required to insure our own development. Self-discipline encourÂ­ ages an ever-enlarging knowledge, an increased sensitivity and the fonra.tion of a true . philosophy of freedom....not the false freedom of pride through autoncmy, belonging or owner-. ship. Through self-discipline, we constantly strengthen our positions; through pride we weaken them.

Self-discipline does not rrean 'doing your thing' contrary to the needs of the group, and it does not rrean that we cannot tailor qur approach to the specific situations within

which we find ourselves. &it it does limit unreal behavior, untrue or devious behavior, 'kind lies' and diplomatic behavior. It does not restrict us from perforrning tasks which we believe to be necessary although unÂ­ pleasant. But it does eliminate the personal irres nsibility of socially determined pride.

It is simply not socially acceptÂ­ able to construct ego-strength; while it is acceptable to express total vulnerability

to the group. And because of such pressures, we are all forced to express our belief in our own ability in private. The result is that our self-esteem must be 'dragged out of

J-: tlring that keeps rrost fo     from behaving creatively is their habits. A habit is sorreÂ­ thing that is preconceived. When you have a habit, you already know how to do sorrething. There are gocx::l habits and bad habits and the value judgment is deternrined by hoo helpful

Creativity requires a steady, determined effort. The more consistently we behave in ways which encourage creativity, the Jrore likely we are to be creative.

Creativity is a learnable state of behavior patterns. It is not regic.â¢ And it is not a quirk of birth.. Some people don't "just have it". Creativity derrands listening to your own logical and sensitive conclusions, not only to the dictates of.the immediate society. who have an interest in resolving

problematic conditions in a positive way and...who are learning to develop their ability to be 'whole'. These are the keys to creativity. To make them work for us to unlock the reality of a 'whole' p:irticip:i.tion in our world we must first discover them to be true for ourselves through personal experience and to then adapt them to our everyday behavior.

JOURNEY


Design can be defined as the process of creative problem-solving; a process of creÂ­ ative, constructive behavior.

lbusewives and hula dancers, gym teachers and geology majors, free- lance writers and

truck farrrers,Indians and idealists, audioÂ­

philes and acrophobes, xylophonists and ZOOM fans are all problem-solvers. Everyone is a problem-solver. Sorre just do it better than others. Since all of us, rrore or less, embark on JTEnY problem-solving journeys, each of us is, rrore or less, involved in the desi&n process. The rore we understand about DESIGN PROCESS, the rrore interesting and meaningful will be our problem-solving journeys.

The DESIGN PROCESS of creative problem-solving describes a series or sequence of events, stages, phases or ENERGY STATES, as we will call-them. Before canpleting a total design journey, it will be necessary to pass through each of these states. Once each state is known through experience, the design process as a whole can be appreciated as a round-

trip which includes intentions, decisions, solutions, actions and evaluations. The seven BJERGY STATES given have been chosen as a synÂ­ thesis from many rrodels of process.

a word about DesignProcess Methods


The Design Prucess is a varied experience. This is largely true because it includes an excursion through even (7) different phases or energy states. And since travel within those phases is sorretimes .simple and yet at times complex, the well-seasoned problem solver carries a varied bag of techniques or approaches to see him through his trip.

Design Methods is the cornrron narre given to the techniques for advancing into and through the phases of the process. They are merely pracÂ­ tical ways for getting-from.one energy state to another.

There are as rrany different methods as there are people with needs for rrethods. A general rule is to find and use those rrethods which best fit the problem as well.as the abilities of the problem solver. To follow that rule and to tailor the rrethods to both problem and problem solver is a sepan:tte task within the problem-solving journey. It is a task similar to that of selecting the route, side roads and overnight stops for an auto trip. Each deciÂ­ sion is based on what will be best for the trip as well as what will be most enjoyed or appreciated by the travelers involved. Just as any competent trip planner would examine the alternate routes on a map and read through several brochures, books or articles before choosing a route for his trip, so should the problem solver read throughÂ·the rrethods which follow, attempt to comprehend their simple techniques and be unafraid to adapt any of them to his special needs or to write addiÂ­ tional ones to meet his individualized problem requirements. Corranon sense suggests that comÂ­ plex problems may utilize complex techniques while simple problems might be handled by simpler tools. It should be clear,.in any event, that just as you wouldn't choose a roving van to go get the groceries,you would not attempt to detennine the cause of an ecological disaster via offhand overall imÂ­ pressions.

Why a Travel Agency?


The Universal Travel Agemy is the place to go when planning a trip. There you may discover many of the various methods for wending your way through the problem-solving process.

Each of the seven sectiais within the 11Agency" represents the progressive stages (or Energy States) of the logical problem-solving sequence. Within each of those segments you will find an Introduction to that part, a series of Methods or techniques for you to sample as aids to helping you passsuccessÂ­ fully through that state, sare specific Travel Tips regarding the environrrent of that state, a Language Guide and a brief list ofhelpful references or Travel Guide.

Although it is most efficient and therefore generally ideal to progress through each state as it is given, it is also normal to vary the sequence in accord with the specific

demands of each problem and problem solver. In the end, the most logical procedure is that special series of events which works best for you and your problem.

resign t-Ethods are merely rreans. or techniques which facilitate certain activities. You will disrover and adapt those methods which best meet your a-m needs quite naturally. But you should always be on the look-out for new methods as well as attempting to invent your am. By getting to knaJ a large munber of methods, you increase your skill and potential as a creative problem solver just as increasing your vocabulary increases your ability to

speak with greater clarity andinsight.

The Universal Design Method is what everyme always looks for. Although many of the resign t-Ethods do cross borders between the Energy States and berome useful in more ways than coe, there is cnly one method which is universal. It is called Checklists.

the Birth of a Problem

The problem-solving process begins :in

a combination of several basic ways:


  1. Someone brings a problem to us and says: "I'd like you to solve/consider/think about/do something to help me out of this situation."

    Example: "What color do you think I

    should paint my car?"

  2. We detect that sorrething in our environment requires replacement, alteration or repair in oroer to be improved.

    Example: ''furn's oie was always so good.

    I wonder what the secret was."

  3. Sane prior experience gnaws at us to deserve our concern.

    Â£xamole: Finding a way to affect the

    city council to save the shoreline.

  4. We intentionally or inadvertently

become enmeshed in a series of problems.

Example: We took the course in order to learn to type and nCM we've got to learn to spell also.

Most of the problems we find time to give serious attention to are those which have been brought to us by others. And while we spend most of our lives solving these "other people's" problems, we may all the while wish we had tine to address ourselves to problems of our CMn making. Perhaps the ulti.r!ate test of creativity is to find the per:ect marriage between our a..m problemÂ­ solving interests and the problems which occupy our energy.

Introduction to Acceptance


--The first J:NE.RGY STATE encountered in the design process is ACCEPI'ANCE.

To accept the problem means to assume responsibility for it. And in order to do that we must voluntarily agree to adapt our personal needs so that they coincide, at least in part, with the as yet UI1Jmown requirements of the problem. In short, ACCEPTANCE is an act of sell-giving. It makes sense to consider it carefully before the fact to decide whether or not your involvement is both pessible and practical. So many people dive lnto problems.with the best of intentions only to discover part way into the fray that they either do

not have the interest or qualifications to continue to the end.

It is important, before the fact, to determine whether or not we have the ability, the time and the energy and to decide whether or not the problem in question

will fit into our existing schedule of priorities. It is always more difficult to back out of a problem after committing ourself to its resolution than it is to reject our participation in it from the outset. Some degree of sell-motivation will be required throughout any effort. That is simply a matter of control and

, persistence. But, if we find ourselves

3 5

  • having to manufacture interest in a problem over and above normal sellÂ­ motivation, it should be clear that we are not 11in tune" with that problem and

should drop it as soon as it is practicable.

Problems do not always come to us pre-stated for ease of solution. They are more than likely hidden, disguised or innocent-appearing; locked inside some emotional distress, attitude conflict, operational dissonance

or distracting arrl superficial outgrc:Mth of another situation. Because of this, it is possible to expend much time and energy trying to untangle the pre-problem mess before getting on with analysis.


To consciously begin working on a problem, it is first necessary to rrake an initial statement of the intent or need which represents the problem situation. Once we recognize and state such a need in search of fulfillment, we can lalow that a problem exists. Before that, we can only sense that some unknown situation demands our attention.


For example, we rray be so distracted by the buzzing of the flies that we hurry out to buy q. fly swatter and fly paper before ever realizing that the more relevant situation is to deal with the holes in the screen.

It is possible to view the entire creative problem-solvingprocess as a sequence of statements concerning the description of the problem situation or condition. We

begin simply,rrove through complex statements derived from analysis and concept and end with a new viewpoint...normally stated simply once again.


(For rrore help in writing statements of intent, see the GUIDE to MFASURABLE OB.ID:TIVES at the end of this book.P.108)

Â·1 WHO AM I?


Because of the limited arrount of time and energy each of us has in his lifetime, choosin 12rnbJerns becomes important. We can't hope to solve them all. With this method you prepare a checklist of personal needs and abilities, long-range plans and expected or current demands. Begin by answering the question, who am I?, at least ten

(10) times. By the seventh or eighth time you will be getting at the heart of who you imagine yourself to be. Next, rrake another list of what you really are. This list, the sum of your experience, is a three-partlist that highlights:

(1) what you l<na..v about,(2) what you can do and

(3) what you believe (knowledge, skills and attitudes). Your entire experience can be included in those three categories. Don't forget to include your strongest likes and disÂ­ likes and your current concept of what your life objectives seem to be.

This will all take quite a bit of time so alla..v several evenings or a weekend to do it slowly.

But it will be worth the effort because this is

that real soul-searching you have always wanted

TO do anyway.Right?

2 PERSONAL PRIORITIES MA1RIX


Using a simple matrix, compare what you expect the problem will demand of your time and energy against the other, existing denands you have facing you.(A matrix is a grid of squares.)

EXAMPLES

  1. List the demands of the problem: Cost in money, time, stress, etc., and place the list on the horizontal columns of the matrix.

  2. List the existing demands on your life on the vertical colwms of the matrix (jobs, duties, etc

  3. Compare the two columns, using an "X" to denote conflicts. Overly conflicting situations sugÂ­ gest that the problem does not fit your current life-style or that those things which c1.1rn:ntly take up your time could stand to be altered or eliminated.

This method gives a brief overall graphic model of the entire problematic situation which faces you and also provides a clue to your expected chances for solving it.:COn't get :in over your head!


3 "WHAT'S 1N IT FOR ME?"


Make a list of all the benefits which may be gained if you choose to accept the responsibility for the problem which faces you. Be as selfish as you like. Remember that direct benefits, such as imnediate pleasures,recognition, money, property and gifts are rrore satisfying than indirect ones.

But don't forget to include the possible developÂ­

ment of skills, the gaining of knowledge and changes in general attitudes which could be use- ful for many other situations. If you bog down, ask a friend or a teacher for help. The benefits should outweigh the costs to you in order to make your life game efficient and worth your effort.

If you do choose to accept the problem, carry your payment schedule along with you. It will be a oonstant incentive to persist if the going gets tough later on.

4 SELF-HYPNarISM

Go to a quiet place. Take a walk alone or shut out the world of people and problems in some way. Clear your mind of everything. Relax. Get very still and try to shake off your total environÂ­ ment. Your body should feel first heavy, then mmb and then asleep. Don't allow anything to distract you from concentrating on nothingness.

When you are relaxed and on the verge of sleep, change your concentration from the void to the positive aspects of the problem situation.

Think how good it will be when it is solved. Think of hew exciting it is to be involved in such an important task and of the feeling of well-being you will have as you continue to

work at that task. Remind yourself of one of


- - /'

the rewartls for solving problems and then

---- .  â¢Â·--?  --: =- ::: -- -  _,;;,

slcwly go back to your "job". The entire process could take as little as five minutes or as long as _one hour and could be repeated daily throughout the course of your problem. Sorrepeople call this "praying". (Also see SIDE TRIPS for rrore on this method.)

3 CONFORMITY

TI1e quickest and easiest way to becorre a part of something is to become as much as possible like that thing. Conform to the problem and you will begin to indicate all of the necessary behavior of acceptance. W:ar the clothes of the problem; talk its language. Go to its favorite places; eat its food; sing its songs; carry its rrottos. Be as much like the problem as you can.

When your friends begin to mention how much like your problem you have become, you will be well on your way to the next energy state.


6GIVE IT UP


Zen philosophy suggests that the attainment of a thing requires the giving up of that thing. This rreans if you want something you must stop concentrating on the thing and the fact that you want it (the product orientation),and you must begin concentrating on what the thing is and on the ways in which it is acquired (process orientation)..

D<AMPLES

  1. If your problem is to get $1,000, "give it up". Instead, get involved with things which earn money like turning your hobby into a profit or getting deep into some noney-producing interest. By thus "giving it up", you will probably end up with more than the mere $1,000 you had as an initial product intention or goal.

11 SEARCH FOR PA'ITERNS


Within every problem there can be found a series

of sub-situations, and for each of those at least one solution is norma.lly available. Based on the

theory that problem solving consists of resolving lots of little conditions toward some collective end or goal, the search =or patterns (previous and typical solutions to individual parts of the problem) becomes meaningful. Clearly, the more patterns which can

be collected, the greater will be the 'vocabulary' solving any particular problem.

FOR EXAMPLE: In the problem of how to

:improve travel by air, we find a typical subsitliation of too-great distances between cities and airports. One mrkÂ­ able response to this has been helicopter service to and from airports and downÂ­ town centers. This pattern then becomes a part of a larger language of patterns to be compiled for use in the airÂ­ traveler problem.

Patterns can be found in nature as well as in previous human response: the way a plant responds to the wind can help us to see ha,,r we might behave in s:imilar situations.

1 aEXPANDING OBJECTIVES

We begin our analytic journey by accepting certain basic intentions or objectives which will achieve our goals. If we follow the course outlined by our objectives, we will be certain to discover new territory in

the line of our desires. Clearly, the analysis state can be broadened and made rrore meaningful to our journey if we conÂ­ tinually attempt to expand and clarify those objectives which guide us.

If each new discovery is fed back to broaden our objectives,then the newly broadened objectives will guide us into ever new territory as in a chain reaction. In the end, those objectives which have been expanded as far as possible can become the specifications for the improved perforrrance you conclude to be the resolution to your problem. The rrore you expand and clarify them, the closer you get to the realization of the solution itself.Also see SIDE TRIPS for rrore on "how to clarify objectives" by

MODELS OF MAN

Introduction to Definition

To determine the meaning of events and

conditions of our world is the work of philosophy. Assigning names and giving definitions to things is the everyday work of all of us. It is the never-ending process of translating the real

world into symbols (words, sounds, images, etc.) which nw must become a conscious part of the process of design.

We begin each problem with a basic definition for that situation in need of improvement.

Such a definition is merely what we mean or

think the problem means as we attempt to describe it at that beginning level of underÂ­ standing. As we progress through the process, our understanding of the meaning of the situation develops into progressively clearer statements until we can say the problem is solved. Usually we carry this refined definition with us until the situation occurs again...at which time we either apply the same hard-won definition to

the new situation or we begin anew, with our higher level of understanding, prepared to develop to even greater heights.

Stating and re-statingdefinitions for problems seems to be the intellectual task of Homo Sapiens. With each statement, whether at the beginning, during the process, or at its conclusion, we invariably mrk toward getting closer to the truth of things..

The degree of comprehension and clarity of our definition of situations at any point in time is dependent on our insight. Our in.sight grws out of our past experience and our knowledge and attitudes concerningthose situations at that time. These concepts, as they are often called, develop and change with experience. The vast array of meanings

assigned to life itself is evidence that diverse. experiences have contributed to the list. There will probably be as rrany different meanings

given to any one thing as there are people

or groups to provide them. The uniqueness of pr-oblem definitions is the prime context for the expression of our individuality or personal philosophy.

At this stage of the DESIGN PROCESS we rm.1st build a bridge between the analysed facts and attributes as we have organized and comprehended

59

them and the resolution of the total situation which comprises those bits and parts. We must conceive a statement which expresses

our new comprehension of the problem now analysed; a statement which, like the "eye of a needle"will provide alignment for all decisions after the fact of its conception. We have reached the point of having to declare what we now believe the problem to mean (at least for this go-around). Later on, if we discover the situation to mean different

or expanded things, we can always change our rnin:i arri try it the next time around. We must now commit ourselves to a spec:iÂ£ic translation of the situation.

Our definition will beccme the filter for all future decisions regarding the problem. Our solution, in the end, will beccme a physical translation of this statement.

ESSENCE-FINDING y MATRIX


In a siJnple matrix inter-relationship, all of the attributes or components of a problem are rated as to their dependence upon or in::iependence from one another. By comparing them, one at a time, against each other,

we determine their degree of dependence or independence within the group as a whole. In this way the key dependent variables are eventually exposed.


In the same way, matrix inter-relationships could be shuffled until groups or large patterns become clear. The large pattern relationships could then be studied as essential overall definition possibilities. A computer, to help with the long manipulation of searching for patterns, can be used to advantage in this last case.

62

Matrices containing vast numbers of.components can get to be quite difficult to m:mipulate.

a complex technique unless you make it

so. It is simply a way to contain a random group within pattern-seekinglimits.

Introduction to------

Ideation


Ideas are rrerely ways to get to where we want to go. That's all they are -no more, no less, If we have no place to go (poorly defined objectives), then ideas won't be of rruch help. Instead they will just ronfuse the issue and keep us from roncentrating

on defining our goals.

If sorreone tosses an idea in our way, it rould really stop us from getting on with our problem-solving journey. And everyÂ­ one always wants to "help out" like that. So one of the rrost useful skills we can . de:velop is to be able to determine, rerogÂ­ nize and identify ideas as rreans to ends so that we can hold them aside until we have decided what we want our objectives to be.

Contrary to popular belief and to rrost of our experience, ideas are really wary easy to acquire. By having only a few idea-generating rrethods in our bag we

can manufacture great quantities of ideas or ways to get where we want to go. By simply knowing where we want to go, we

are at once in a position to find many ways to get there.

Having lots of ideas when we are ready to use them makes it possible for us to be able to select better ideas and waste less effort with unimportant alternatives .

1 BRAINSTORMING


Brainstorming is one of the most useful and misunderstood of the ideation rrethods. It is useful because any group of 4 to 12 persons can quickly learn to rranufacture scores of ideas for any problem situation in very short periods of time. Fifty ideas in five minutes is not an unusually large number using brainÂ­ storming rules. It is misunderstood because the name has become synonyrrous with any single idea and people mistakenly think that they can produce ideas in any session they choose to call a brainstorming session without following the idea-generatingrules.

The originator of brainstorming, Alex Osborn, lays down four requirements for all who participate in a session. Anyone can learn to apply them. But if ignored, the session is automatically retarded.

  1. Defer judgment. (Criticism col!lt.:afterward.)

  2. Free-wheel. (Hang loose.)

  3. Tag on. (Don't wait for an idea. Muke another one out of the last one given by changing it in some way.)

  4. Qt.!antity is wanted. (Don't hold back for a minute.)

Restrict the sessions to about fifteen (15) minutes at most,and be sure everyone is familiar with the problem before beginning. A followup session, using the sarre participants on the next day or so,is a good way to pick up all of the "after-thoughts".

68

We use the words (verbs) to m:mipulate the subject by changing its position or by altering its shape, function, size, etc. Manipulative verbs can produce a series of :i.deas in a short time. For problem solvers who must work alone, this rrethod is a "natural".

Introduction to

Idea-Selecting idea

â¢

Now that we know where it is that we want to go (definition) and now that we have devised and collected many alternate ways (ideas) for getting there, the next logical step on the journey will be to select one or rrore of these "ways" from the many we have gathered. We must now decide which idea fulfills the requireÂ­ rrents of our objectives better than all of the others.

To be able to choose "the best way", all we need do is to get rrore and rrore specific in our description of our definition. The rrore clearly that we can state our intentions for th behavÂ­ ior of elerrents of the situation, the easier it will be to find the right m2ans for filling that bill.

It's all just that simple. If we get bogged down, we rrerely clarify the definition a bit rrore and go on again. Now, it is no big problem to select one way from just a few ways but the rrore alternatives we have to choose from, the m:>re important it becorres to spell out the details of our goal. Thus, in selecting one idea from the many we must assign a value to each of them in order to oompare their relative worth. And

we can evaluate ideas by rating them in accordÂ­ ance with how well they satisfy our definition.


In the exarrple of Going to Boston, we

rould unoover a large number of alternative routes for getting there. We will thereÂ­ fore be forced back to our definition for guidelines to the selection of one way from the many. If our definition is not clear,it will have to be further clariÂ­ fied. In the end,the route chosen will be the one which best fulfills all of our desired outcorres.

Methods for Idea-Selecting

  1. Screening by Personal Opinion

  2. Ideas--Objectives Comparison

  3. The PotpourTi Method

  4. The Indian Scout Technique

  5. The Equal to or Better Than Method


1 SCRE!NING BY PERSONAL OPINION

To select your choice from many possibilities is to evaluate (assign value) according to your personal opinion. You do this by listÂ­ ing your alternatives (which happen to be ideas in this case),and you check them against your offhand or organized overall appraisal.

Eventually, an order of preferences emerges by a process of elimination.

In short,you compare your choices, one against the other, deciding which one or ones you prefer rrost, then which one second, etc. until all al ternatives have been.sifted through your "opinion" screen. The comprehensiveness of your screen

is of course dependent on your consideration of the problem's importance. Situations which call for choosing from a great number of ideas might benefit from the "trade off" or KING-OFÂ­ THE-MOUNTAIN technique,


You may recognize this method as the one most corrm:>nly used by both yourself and others.

What you know, believe and can do (knowledge, attitudes and skills) becoires the format for your opinions and you judge everything in your environment according to the way you arrange those opinions at the time of judgment.

76

2 IDEAS-OBJECTIVES COMPARISON

The basic systematic seiection technique is to compare goals, objectives and intentions with the alternate means (ideas) for achieving those desired results. The best measure of value, when attempting to determine which alÂ­ ternative to follow, is always a clearly stated, specific and itemized list of objecÂ­ tives. By such.comparison, you methodically discard those ideas which do not work in some way until only those which are generally satisfactory remain.

An excellent scoreboard for such comparisons is the matrix, or two dimensional graph, with your objectives listed on one axis and your ideas listed on the other. Scoring is simple: write YES at intersectio:rs where ideas meet the criteria of the objectives and NO where they do not. MAYBE or(?) could be used when an uncertainty exists (suggestingmore study). More complex situations may require a 0-9 numerical evaluation and still more complex situations may demand that both objectives and ideas be broken down into very specific parts so that rore keen decisions can be made.

-) CATEGORIZATION OF IDEAS is a helpful preÂ­ selection operation. If all ideas are organÂ­ ized into rore manageable groups of similar kinds of things, a great number of ideas can be evaluated quickly. This is a generally useful method which can be adapted in intensity to any problem situation.


If the purpose of idea-findingis to gather as many alternatives as possible, then idea-selecting might easily be defined as the time for extracting the best parts of all those ideas. Very directly, therefore, the POTPOURRI method suggests that

all ideas which are collected be discarded in favor of still another idea which attempts to combine the best features of them all.

A simple technique for sifting out those "best features" of ideas is to turn each idea into (5) five or (10) ten additional ideas by improving

or warying its basic scheme. (When you get going, it's not unusual to find yourself doubling your idea list in a fraction of the time it took to gather the first ones.) When each idea is surÂ­ rounded by a series of variations on itself,the salient features of the original will probably

be clearly exposed. 77


EXAMPLE: If ideas 1,2, and 3 are:

  1. to take a vacation

  2. to continue working

  3. to find a vacation substitute

    A POTPOURRI which combines all three might be:

  4. to turn work into a vacation;

A scheme which utilizes the essential concepts all (3) three original ideas.

4 THE INDIAN scour

The most corrmonly practiced technique for evaluÂ­ ating and selecting ideas is to try them out ahead of time via the use of some simulation device. Like the Indian scouts of the last cenÂ­ tury, you go up ahead to see what it's going to be like when the main force arrives. You check things out to improve your chances of avoiding an ambush or other disaster. This method is

based on the premise that if you use your :imaginÂ­ ation (or other form of simulated reality) to experience each of your ideas,you will be in

a better position to choose from among them. That idea which provides the best experience with the least amount of hazard is your obvious choice. The Indian Scout technique attempts to answer the question, "What could possibly happen if you actually carried this idea to completion?"

A rating system for this approach could simply be a few words of commentary following each "dry run11 , IIJ.lthough any other symbols for value will work, if they are properly chosen.

(The Program Evaluation Review Technique, or P.E.R.T., provides an organized procedure for exploring

this method in depth. With P.E.R.T., you attempt

a

to determine "the most critical path" in order to avoid being victimized by your ignorance of its importance later on.)


_.,.. .


EQUAL TO OR BEITER THAN


Another way of defining the ideation (or search for ideas) phase of the design process is to see it as the attempt to find lffil1Y ways to get to the same place. F:r'Om that standpoint, the selection of ideas phase can be understood as a determination of which of our ideas are better than others and which of them are equal to others in value. The rating of ideas is prerequisite to completing any evaluation or selection.

78

Still,once all of our ideas gathered to meet a specific situation have been rated, they can be further evaluated by an attempt to trade them off for "equal to or better than" subÂ­ stitutions.

The simple procedure followed here is to attempt to find additional ideas which might be accepted as more acceptable,further improved or more efficient versions of the originalideas..If substitutions can be found,we not only gain additional alternatives but we also acquire insight for assigning comparative value to those ideaswe already have.

Introduction to Implementation

At last we reach the action state. This is what we have all been waiting for...actually doing

scmething al::out solving the defined problem itself. Now that we have thought out and carefully determined a strategy, the foundations are laid

for a positive completion of the trip. Implementation is what most of us imagine the entire problem-solving process to be...getting going...doing something about the problem. We don't want to be bothered by all that preliminary "fooling around". We want to act on the first idea which seems like a good one. And most of us actually do operate in just that natural,

not always creative manner.

Hopefully, travelers who have followed a systematic sequence as outlined in this guideÂ­ rook are no longer the awkward problem-solving tourists who would act on impulse alone.

Instead, by applying the logic of the design process, they should now be more balanced, integrated and holistic, well-seasoned travelers. They should now be prepared to enter the tactical, active state of translating their carefully selected alternative (idea) into the reality of

a solution to their problem. They should now be excited by the pleasurable experience of

kncwing where they are going and why: while enjoying the security of having explored rrany alternate concepts and routes.

Implementation begins by simply picking up the phone and ordering a round trip ticket to your destination. It means "get going". You are ready for action. The time has oome for you to put your chosen idea(s) to the test.

    1TiiE TIME-TASK SCHEOOLE

    A basic way to get on with the tactical phase of your problem excursion is to rrake a time and task schedule. The procedurâ¬ for this is:

  2. Decide how rrany and what kind of tasks are involved in performing the selected idea requirements. Find the answer to the question, "What are all the steps which must be taken in order to completeÂ·this thing?"

  3. Determine the exact arrount of time you have for the overall project.

    82

  4. Assign, :in the nost reasonable way you can, portions of the total time to each of the steps required.

  5. Prepare a graphic display (a piece of paper will do) which shows the relationship of time to your tasks.

  6. Allow the time-task schedule to guide you through the implementation phase.


2 BRAINWASHING


The time for taking.action on an idea is not very much different from the t:i.rre for accepting the resp::msibility for solving the problem at the outset. The only difference is that in the beginn:ing what lies ahead is unknown. By nowÂ­ we have gone through five (5) phases of a systematic excursion,and we should be confident. But, physical and errotional strength is probably still required for "getting it on". We may even have to go back to some of the self-motivation methods from the initial phase of the process and bra:inwash all misgivings and fears from our head so that we might have the courage to go on. W: must reconvince ourselves of the logic of our pnxess and realize that, after all, the very personal reason rrost of us have for be-

ginning any design journey is that we intend to improve our current position by expanding our experience.

Note: BRAINWASHING is a pre-implementation method and is useful in combination with all other implerrentation methods.

3 PERFORMANCE SP!x:IFICATION


Ideas can be changed into action by going through a process of breaking them down into a group of specific and_intended behaviors. Once we have specified the exact perform:mce we desire to achieve from our action-idea scheme, all that rerra.ins is to translate it into real materials or actions.

In essence, this is a technique for a continual elaboration on the idea until it stops being abstract and starts being real. The rrore that each specific aspect of the idea can be stated in termsof perforrrance,the closer that.idea comes to being realized (turned into reality).

[Batteries could be self-charging.]

Note! If the exact specification of performances begins to look like a list of exactly specified objectives, it is because they are synonyrrous.

order to be stipulated or predicted. It's always the sarre issue: If you don't know where you want to go, you will never know when you arrive;and the more you know about where you are going,the closer you are to actually being there.

ATIRIBUTEANALOG or YOU CAN BUTI.AD CO.MRJTER AT HOME IN YOUR SPARE TIME

The slide rule is an analog computer. With a set of scales which relates to another scale,

the relationships may be varied within established limits to reveal resultant values. A centigradeÂ­ Fahrenheit thermometer does the same thing with the mercury doing the sliding up and down. And so do certain children's construction kits which contain prograrrmed interchangeable parts able to be assembled into many variations of the sarre things if prescribed operations are followed.

If your idea has definitely fixed limits and yet could take a wide variety of forms, you ma.y wish to build an analog computer to use as a tool for studying many possible combinations which could be achieved within those limits.

Similar to a morphological analysis, your "comÂ­ puter''allows any combinationÂ· of potentials to be assembled as long as those combinations stay within the prescribed limits of the idea. Your computer may be linear or circular. Your hand or pencil may be the only mving part. It can take many shapes, forms and variations. Once the relationship limitations are discovered and applied to the attributes of the idea, all variations of form are irronediately accessible

via such a tool.


6 LIVE UP TO YOUR NAME


Just as problems are difficult to perceive until defined, ideas are also often hard to realize until they are identified by a name. A way to implement your chosen idea, therefore, is to give it a narre or write a pun in reference to it or assign a cliche which-describes it. Then try your best to live up to that narre.

'EXAMPLE:

Suppose your idea was to triple the enrollment of the local Eco-Action group by throwinga recycling party. Give the party a name: LetIs say you call it "Sl!\3.shing Good Time". vihat remains is to live up to that name. Have the band call themselves the "Can Srrashers11â¢ Invent a dance called the "Carton 'Iwister".

Print'invites'on can bottoms and tops. Have a can-smashing competition and a bottleÂ­ breaking race, etc. It's easy. Once you've got a title, what remains is merely to fill in the blanks.

Here are twenty (20) additional implerrentation methods. They are merely sorre of the ways that artists get it on. Although these methods have been gleaned from the visual design disciplines, it is not W1likely to find them being used by other artful and scientific designers (creative problem solvers) of other disciplines.

l,,mether or not a discipline is corrrnonly called Art or Science, a problem rerrains a problem within any discipline. Its truths must be uncovered (scientific activity) and those truths must be expressed( artistic activity).

And the methods foW1d in this FLFA MARKET are adaptable to nany diverse problem conditions.

A.) PRINCIPLES OF DESIGN

Irnplerrenting ideas is often defined as synthesizing wholes from parts. Many compositional rules and principles exist for putting things together, but one cannon set of principles which refers to all of them is:

HARMONY or Recognizable similarity for all parts of the whole

CONTRAsr or Recognizable difference for all parts of the whole

BALANCE or Rerognizable stability for all parts of the vtiole

ORDER or Recognizable pattern of organization to the whole

UNITY or Recognizable collectiveness for all . parts of the whole

Many designers use these principles either singly or in rombination to guide their assemblages.

The fact that the Principles of Design are easily translated from and attributed to the

natural laws of physical behavior attests to their universal validity.

B. ) DIAGRAMS AND SCHD1ATICS

Many designers begin their implementation phase with scribbled diagrams and scherratics to symbolize relationships between the parts of their problems. They search, via sketchy organizational diagrams and lists, for the relationships which will link the factors, aspects or components of their problem. We hear such diagrams called "bubble" diagrams, flow charts, layouts,

organizational charts, etc. Through repetition, and by trial and error, the sketches eventually emerge as refined definitive relationship â¢ drawings which are then translated into physical rraterials.

  1. MODELS

    Although we realize that anything can be used as a rnodel for the study of another thing, some problem situations just seem

    to call for small "scale" models as a method for rroving from the abstract to the real.

    Complex fonns and difficult-to-visualize ideas derrand to be "rrocked uP" in order for "parts" to be kept in context with "wholes". The nornal procedure is to begin with rough "study" or "sketch" rrodels and to work through a series of rrodels until a " mcx:lel" or "prototype" is developed.

  2. TOPSY

Large numbers of designers have no M.O. (rrodus operandus, or method of operation) except that it might be called TOPSY. They simply "let it happen", "let nature take her course" or "work it on out". This non- directed approach has shortcomings, such as difficulties with setting time limits, which become the undoing of rrany problems and problem solvers. Still, with persistence and energy, this method can be made to work. Because guidelines are W1covered by bits and pieces during the process, the TOPSY approach is like operating in the dark: a situation

which causes loss of confidence and thus begins to take its toll among those who use it.

  1. ) FOLLOW A STI-IILAR MODEL

    To locate a problem similar to yours which was solved to the satisfaction of all conÂ­ cerned is another common technique. You find out how soireone else solved vour DrobÂ­ lem (or one like it) and you solve yours in the sam2 fashion.

    This approach, though often misnamed "cribbing" is really a form of apprenticeship. When we use it, and rrost of us do, we accept the fact that we wish to learn by follo.-ri.ng a leader and that perhaps we are t,ri.se enough to realize how foolish it would be to overtly avoid the experience of history. It is fine to try to be very independent, but to avoid the library so as to protect yourself from being influenced by solutions of others suggests a need to consider the interdependence of all things.

  2. ) PA'ITERN LANGUAGE

    Within every problem of environmental design, many sub-problems exist. (This is also true of all other problems.) For each sub-problem, socially, psychologically and physicallyÂ­ ncceptable solutions already exist. If a

    87

    large number of these sub-problems within a system can be identified as to their position or context, and if their ac-ceptable solutions can be logically recalled, a language of the "patterns" of the problem begins to emerge. The PA'.ITERN LANGUAGE rrethod suggests using that language to derive new systems out of the organized bits and pieces of the old. (This regenerative technique is still in developrrent by a gr'OUp in Berkeley under

    the direction of C. J. Alexander, an architect.)

  3. ) AECHCTYPICAL FORM

    Internal and external forces and pressures tend to give things archetypical forms which reflect response to such force. If change is slow and evolutionary we eventually learn the archetypes of our environment and we respond to those rather than to reality itself. A child draws a gable roof and

    bearing walls to represent a house. And such a drawing represents the archetype of house.

    All things have archetypes; they can be thoug)"lt of as the traditional or original prototypes of things.

    This design technique approaches the synÂ­ thesis of new things by casting them within the rrold of the archetype. Books are flat and rectangular, churches point to the sky, cups are cylinders or tapered cylinders, etc.


  4. ) GRIDS OR COMMON DENOMINATORS

Ideas for complex problems are often implemented by use of a comrron denominatorÂ­ an element, unit or component which gives every part of the whole a comrron relationÂ­ ship. If a two-dimensional grid can organize an extremely complex situation like land ownership,it can also organize other multiÂ­ part situations. \.\hen the grid is expanded to three dirrensions, an organized f amework exists within which large complex situations such as architectural designs can be implemented. Total systems become much more manageable within such frameworks, both during the design phase and later on during their operation. (This three-dimensional grid concept for the organization of total systems is often referred to as FIEID

THIDRY. ) GRIDS c.an take any shape

(angularity) dictated by the problem context.

I.) ESSENTIAL UNIT BUILDING BLOCK

A House of Cards and a "castle" made from children's building blocks are examples of larger things achieved by assembling srell

88

identical units and by following their "rules" or limits of assembly. In a similar way, other large, complex things can be constructed. This method begins with a search for an essential unit which can later be assembled in quantity to achieve large and complex configurations not easily possible by other means. The "units" grow into large systems by being allowed to follow the rules of interconnecÂ­ tion which must be designed into their similar shapes or forms. The Essential Unit Building Block can be seen to be a variation of the Grid or Comrron Denominator Method. Another name used for this techÂ­ nique is UNIT GROWTH.

J. ) HOLISTIC OR TOTAL FORM

The Unit Growth approach begins with snall units and assembles them into larger wholes. The opposite approach, often referred to as the Sculptural Method, begins with whole assemblages conceived as abstract configu_.-riaÂ­ tions and proceeds to break those wholes down into orderly systems of smaller components. It should be clear that no natter which of the two (UNIT GROWTH OR HOLISTIC) rrethods is chosen, it is not

long before the other must also be conÂ­ sidered. Only so rrany small units ma.y be assembled before the whole must be given serious thought;just as wholes can be refined only so far before attention must be given to the components needed to realize them.

K.) RESPONSE TO HUMAN NEEDS

This rnethod contends that all problem solutions must be acceptable response to the human needs which inspired them in the first place. And, rroreover, that to solve any problematic situation completely is to design a solution which responds to all hurran needs. Complete lists of hwnan needs are not available,but researchers a..'l'"'e fast collecting them. In the interim, the lists which are available suffice to produce

solutions with far more humanistic roncems than were previously possible. Via this technique, the idea being implemented is checked against each "need" on the list and revised to comply with being a favorable response to each individual need as well as to combinations of needs and to the whole. Since it appears that human indiÂ­ viduality is the result of the separate, unique proportions we have of a corrmon

set of needs, we can be sure that our

problem implementation will never please all.


89

With this rrethod, the essence or core of the idea is first extracted and clarified and then used as the ultirrate decision-making screen for all further decisions in the implementation phase. Such an approach is like a mini-version of the entire problemÂ­ solving process. It distills a definition (essence) from a situation and proceeds to use that definition as a primary source for the evaluation of all other decisions perÂ­ taining to the situation. Getting the essence of the idea realized is all that rratters. Wi.en other objectives enter into the decision-making process, they always remain secondary to the one definition.

And, in the end, the solution reflects such concentration of attention.

M.) LET GEORGE DO IT

One method for entirely circumventing the personal implementation of an idea is to get a "pa.tent" on the thing and sell it to someone else who is in a better position to act on it than you are. Simply, "draw it up" (which takes a little bit of "working out" to accanplish in itself), hire a pa.tent attorney to authorize a pa.tent search, wait for the results and then go out looking for a developer who is willing to buy your scheme.

N. ) CONSULTANTS TEAM

Become a team leader. Break your idea down into the various categories which can be treated by experts. If, for instance, your idea deals with the developrrent of a new product, divide iÂ± into the separate areas of rrarket analysis, design, production,

advertising, distribution, etc. Arrange to meet the various consultant teams who know each

of those areas best. You act as the coordinator ,;..iho resolves all of the opinions of your "expert" staff. The theory here is that the more people you get in on the act, the better will be the total performance.

The dangers are either that the performance will have so rrany prllTE. donnas it will be difficult to recognize the idea beneath it or that the idea will lose sight of its objectives due to one of the experts being stronger than the coordinator.


  1. STRUCTURAL LIMITS METHOD

    Although,this method is corrmon to engineers, it.is nonetheless adaptable to other problems. Every assemblage has a structural fram:work

    which holds it together and stabilizes its fonn.     1. BIONICS

      Bionics is a variation on the MODELS approach. The difference is that the bionic model is a natural one. For every possible idea there is a natural counterÂ­ part (or at least via SYNICTICS there is a way to find a relationship between the idea and Nature). By studying how the

      natural model works and how it achieves its ends, the implementation of your idea will find its guidelines.

      Since rran is a part of nature and since his concoctions are therefore also a part of nature, it is easy to understand ho:,., practical it might be to allow nature to rrodel the behavior of human intentions.

    2. RESPONSE TO ROLE-PLAYING

This is another "preview" method. It is a technique of becoming the iterns being designed or the people being affected by

those ideas through use of the imagination. It is a process of living through the experience of implementation before it actually happens and of responding to that role-playing experience by a more informed implementation phase. The pre-experience allows all fears to be acted out and eliminated and provides the security of ''having been there before" when you literally take action. Psychologists

often refer to this techniaue as "anxiety" or worrying about what might h3.ppen before it actually does take place. So, if you do this anyway, you might develop it as a tool.


R. ) NOTATION SYSTEMS

If your job requires you to implerrent great numbers of similar complex problems, it JTE.Y be advantageous to your process to design your own notation system. Notations, like numbers and words, are rrerely other symbols

9 1

for reality. We find symbolism helpful in ooping with complex reality\and it is clear that notation systems have helped man to develop further than any other species. His ability to thin. in symbols is considered

to be his pri.m:lly unique attribute airong the animals.

A notation system can help you to visualize large quantities of information simultaneously. It can save needless repetition of operations during developmental processes,and it can insure the inclusion of necessary considera-

tions which might otherwise be inadvertently ignored. Take a look at musical notation for inspiration; remembering that a few

symbols can greatly simplify repetitive processes.

S. ) INSPIRATION OR LIGHI'NING BOLT

Lots of problem solvers use the age-old technique of just waiting around for inspiration. They read, talk, scribble and wait. They know about their problem and now expect the lightning bolt of inspira- tion to hit them in the back of the neck.

Â¼hen it hits, they shout something like "Eureka" and then get on with it. This method is often used for "definition" and "ideation" as well as implementation. Osborn calls it "incubation", and its general syrrbol is a light bulb turning on over the head of the designer. This approach is probably the rrost untrustt.,.JQrthy of the lot since it is highly dependent on factors outside of

our control, which mislead many to believe in magic, fate and design-by-luck as substitutes for goal achieverrent by intention.


  1. TRIAL AND ERROR

    Evolution and the law of natural selection both describe this well-kn0vm technique for turning ideas into reality. You simply do it and evaluate it so that you can do it again and againwith (hopefully) less and less error. No rratter how sophisticated our rrethods become, we always end up paying lip service to the TRIAL and ERROR method because when we a.re totally finished with the implementation and evaluation of a problem-solving journey we invariably say, "The next time I try this kind of thing, I certainly won't mai<e the errors that were rrade this time."

    Introduction to Evaluation ..

    One final Energy State remains - Evaluation - the time taken at the end of the problem-solving journey to look back at the entire process. We look back

    to determine how far we have tr>aveled and how valuable the journey has been so that future tr>ips will be more smooth.


    Once more we must rely on the set of objectives which began to take form at the start of the process and which has been developing all along the way.

    For in the end the evaluation phase is a naster comparison of our record of accomplishments against that list of refined hopes and intentions called our objectives. Evaluation is a measurement of hoo far or how much (quantity) and hoo well or how rich (quality). The sum of the two represents "value" or what the journey has been worth. And it cannot be accomplished without having laid the proper foundation of objectives. We won't be able

    to realistically measure how far we have traveled or hoo rich the trip has been if we didn't know and clearly state where it was that we intended to go in the first place.

    It becomes clear, after a trip or two, that journeys through the design process can be digested to the simple definition of defining, achieving and measuring objectives"; that the problem-solving process is really just the systenatic series of events which leads us to determine how well we

    can make our dreams come true and advance one rrore increment on the great spiral continuum of life.

    2 "WHJELSE HAS AN OPINION?"

    At first glance, writing a questionnaire seems easy. But you can be sure that the preparation of "a survey of user or public opinion which collects measurable results" requires both skill and strict attention. Most questionnaires achieve

    little in terms of evaluative results. They merely pacify those who prepare them with "general feelÂ­ ings" that things went either right or wrong or somewhere in.between and offer no real help for improvement.

    The l<:ey to preparing an evaluative questionnaire is identical to that for preparing objectives: The answers obtained must be received in a form which is measurable and relative to improvement. Here are some definite methods for preparing such a questionnaire.

    00 NOT ASK GENERAL QUESTIONS

    You'll only get general or stereotyped answers.

    WATCH YOUR LANGUAGE

    Words are symbols and everyone symbolizes reality in a different way.

    TRY TO GET ANSWERS TRANSLATEDINTO MORE THAN ONE

    FORM

    Asl<: for words and pictures or for two descripÂ­ tions of the samething.

    OON'T ASK "FOREIGNERS"TO USE YOUR LANGUAGE

    Don't expect them to understand your special jargon the way you do.

    NARROW OOWN

    Work from the general to the specific so an order is clearly established

    AVOID STRANGENESS

    Make it friendly and remember that what seems friendly to you may.still be strange to others. People are not themselves in a strange situation.

    OON'T BE A SELF-FULJ'ILLING PROPHET

    Don't beg for certain answers which support your opinion. Such an approach makes the questionnaire meaningless.

    IX)N'T DRAG IT our

    What interests you may not be all that important to others.

    GIVE A REWARD

    Make it worthwhile to fill out your questionnaire. Provide sanethingthat can be carried away.

    After all, you are taking their questionnaire away to keep for yourself.

    BE DIRECT

    Don't be vague or poetic.Â·You couldn't use answers which came in that form. 97

    KEEP A RECORD OF WHICH QUESTIONS REIATE TO WHICH OF YOUR OBJECTIVES

    Avoid confusion by preparing ahead of tin-e.

    USE A NUMERICAL SCALE,SEMANTIC DIFFERENI'IAL OR SlliIIAR DEVICE

    Tallying will be easier and answering will also be simplified if some consistent method is provided.

    EXAMPLES: How do you think the visual appearÂ­ ance of the product will be accepted by the general public?

Looking back over a completed journey is a mellowing experience. The good times a1;d bad tend to fuse together to become a single memory or general impression. The general impression is merely accented by the most impressive situations encountere<,i; minor pleasures and acquisitions are as easily forgotten as are the minor difficulties and sub-problems. As we lose sight of the srrall experiences and begin to remember only the rrajor "ports of call", we set ourselves up once again to forget the joy and reality of process orientation. We recall our total, multi-event experience as but a series of products or destinations.

Thinking th s way makes improvement difficult since the task of determining value can only become a search of the superficial. By viewing our process of interwoven and diverse activities as the necessary trivia occurring between goals we rrake a survey of benefits accrued and losses suffered all but impossible.

Learning from our experiences requires us to concentrate on their inter-relationships. If

we wish to improve our problem-solving abilities, we must work toward improving the bits and pieces of the problem-solving process.

Conscious travel through the seven ENERGY STATES of the design process makes the gathering and organizing of "notes" and memorabilia easier.

And with such materials to review, the potential for learning from our mistakes is improved.

By knowing the general conditions of the major areas of activity before our journey we can begin to concentrate on and enjoy the many events which occur along the way. And with

such realization, the improvements and behavioral changes mich comprise a learning condition

can be achieved.

101


We all derive separate and unique values from our experiences. We then go on to judge future experiences against those values and to rrodify and formulate new values in the process. We call this process 'learning', a by-product of life.

a

During the course of presenting the seven Energy States and the many methods of the problemÂ­ solving process, our intention has been to help you realize a creative necessity for locating personally-tailored balance between the need to set and realize goals and the need to enjoy life as it unfolds. To appreciate the entirety of life, we believe it is necessary to develop skill in walking the fence between processÂ­ awareness and goals-achievement. And we hope your personal discovery of this fundamental reÂ­ quirement has been enjoyable.

To help remind yourself of the need for this balance c:mdition, you might imagine the diffÂ­ erence in time between arTival at the various stations on a railway schedule or between stops on a bus line. It takes time, often lots of it, to reach goals. The rroments of amievement approach, arrive and pass and we are off once more to the next destination. In the end, it is clear that we have spent the vast portion of our life in the process of going and only a very small part of it in arriving.

What most people refer to as creativity is merely the breaking of some rule or habit withÂ­ out causing an undle.arrount of stress or tra.tnna to those people concerned. Actually, creative behavior could be more truly defined as behavior

which is both subjectively and objectively whole, is free fran pride and the other "deadly sins", is constructively discontented, has a willingness to succeed and is fearless in the face of rules or habits--.

Here are a series of games designed to help with the learning and development of those "tra.i ts ".

Since any change in behavior denotes the breaking of a habit, any game which produces a change is a habit-breaking exercise.

Guide to Measurable Objectives.-_

-â¢â¢lf-t -Â·

The primary key to creative problem solving is to become aware of where it is that we are headed and why we want to go to

that place; in short, what is our goal and what are our objectives.

It makes little sense to be on our way if we


:Â·::,::

. .


.,.


Â·-'}: â¢.(

have no way of knowing when we arrive at our goal.

Problems always begin as some form of initial intention or objective. As the problem solver pursues his initial intentions, those desires berome more and more clear and specific. The more specific they become, the easier it is to recognize their achievement. Therefore:

To make objectives measurable, it is

necessary to make them more clear and specific.

AA objective is a statement of some desired or intended outcome to be accomplished within a stated series of constraints. If statements of

108

--, . - - ..

J

in . Â· 11

objectives are not giâ¢ven

  • terms which can

be clearly and me surably realized, we Wl always be uncertain s to the success or degree of their attalJlITlent.

Simply, we can think of o jectives as that list of actions we think J..IDportant to take if our goal is to be realized, In other

words, our objectives comprise all of the things we hope to accomplish to the point of being able to say that our goal has been achieved. For example: a

school will define a curriculum of courses or subjects required to obtain a diplana or degree. Fach subject has a separate set

of requisites, and once all of the

tasks for each component of the curricu um are satisfied, the certificate is issued.

If we consider the diplorre/degree/certificate

(or the education represented by that paper) as the goal, then the measurable objectives become all of the tasks required to earn or achieve it. Translating goals into lists of objectives is a personal ma.tter and derives from analysis

and individual experience. It is only out of the quantity and quality of our individual objectives leading to camron goals that we begin to set standards of excellence.


The design process can be viewed as a series of restatements of objective : beginning with initial objectives, passing through several refinements of those statements and ending with a new view of those statements; always getting closer to clear and specific measurable objectives.

OBJECTIVES SUCH PS:

I want to go to Europe

I want to study architecture I'd like to get rich,

I'm determined to ma.rry that girl

cannot be measured until clear, specific paraÂ­ meters are assigned to each of them. As they stand, such statements are merely general destinations and must be restated as a series of objectives which are attai.rable only if certain requirements, yet to be stated, are met.

Clearly, stating a goal is quite simple: but preparing an acceptable, measurable "curriculum" for attaining a goal is hard, important work.

Simply then, to rreasure an objective is to be

able to know when you have reached it.

"I want to go to Boston" is an immeasurable statement. But answers to the question "How will I know when I get there?" will provide the measures needed to get on our way in a

Objectives form the path to goals. It is desirable although normally unrealistic to inagine that

we can define a complete, acceptable list of them at the outset of a problem-solving journey. Because of this, we are usually required to make "initial suggestions" and

keep the JX)tential for change constantly in mind. For rrore see Preparing Instructional Objectives and

Goal Analysis by Robert Mager ( FearonÂ· Press)

    EXAMPLE: If you wanted to establish a new viewpoint regarding a situation, you could gather together a srrall group of associates and take an excursion through the process as outlined by Gordon in his book.     Procedure for

    Self-Hypnosis

    Hypnosis is a way of reaching the sub-conscious mind with messages. Self-hypnosis is the key to all mind-trips. Whatever you are into or want to get into, self-hypnosis is the basic method. Essentially, it is a method of telling yourself what you want to be able to do by freeing yourself of your conscious mind and by getting to the inner mind through your subÂ­ conscious mind. It is a relaxation technique.

    Deep prayer, meditation, EEG feedback, mind control, reevaluation counseling, Zen, karate, positive thinking, ESP, cosmic consciousness, etc., all begin with self-hypnosis of one form or another.

    It's all a matter of getting yourself into a

    "receptive state ". When you are ready to receive):...,.... Â· then you can put the positive change stuff inside t â¢ yourself and begin to change accordingly.

    Hypnosis can't make you go against your own will. You can't be told or tell yourself to do some- thing you don't want to o and then be made to do it.

    The hypnm:ic state is the state between being awake (conscious) and asleep (unconscious). It is the state of half-asleep and half-awake or sub-conscious. This "boundary of sleep" state is your suggestive or receptive state. What you are told to do in this state is more impressive to you.

    The basic procedure is as follows:(approx. time: 20 minutes).

    1. State your purpose; your objective for using hypnosis.

    2. Get into the hypnotic state

      1. Relax--loosen clothing--lie down or stretch out and get as loose as possible

      2. Close your eyes (to block out external consciousness)

      3. Let go of controlling your body from the top of your head to your to s--part by part--tighten each part from eyes and

        1 16

        jaws to feet and the;let them go. Totally relax. Put your body to sleep.

        ‌It must be quiet. There can be no "conscious awakeness" trying to vX:>rk against you.

      4. Go deeper and deeper into your sub-conscious mind. Turn your body into silly putty. Imagine that you are swaying gently back and forth in a hammock in a quiet garden

        or that you are going down an elevator which gets you deeper into sleep with each floor, etc.

      5. It all takes practice and it feels very good. Relaxing makes you feel better afterward. This is also known as Hatha Yoga Relaxation.

      6. Relax your mind by fixing it on one inanimate thing like a clock ticking or

        the hum of the air conditioner.Don't think. Feel. Lose the here and now. Become mindless and senseless.

    3. Plant your suggestions. (Since you can't talk to yourself without becoming conscious again--you will need a friend or a tape recorder to slowly and rhythmically tell you what you want to learn to do.)

      1. Mentally describe the new desired behavior in detail. Make the change vivid and visual.

      2. Imagine yourself going through the changed behavior at least five times in succession.

      3. Step outside of yourself and watch yourself doing it one more time.

      4. Suggest some positive,rewarding experience as a benefit from the new behavior.

    4. Wake yourself with confidence.

      1. Tell yourself that as you awake and get up, you will feel better, have greater confidence in your new behavior and that in general you are on a positive trip.

    5. Play your tape each night or each morning for six days and you will probably have

self-hypnotized yourself into doing something you have always wanted to do.

Self-hypnosis is useful for learning, loving, remembering, accepting and reprogramming to "forget" bad experiences by changing them to good memories.

Auto-suggestions only have a life-span of about 36 hours so until you truly learn to change your

behavior, you will need to reinforce yourself by listening to your tape for at least six days.

If you normally listen to yourself, your own voice on a tape will be sufficient; if you need to be told by someone else before you will listen, get a strong friend to record your suggested messages.

COMMUNICATION involves transferring a meaning which is in your mind through the environment to the mind of your intencted receiver. The meaning must pass through your background and be formed by your ability as well as pass through the background and ability d:iÂ£ferences of the receiver.

THE DEI'ERMINANTS OF SUCCESSFUL CCMMUNICATION

SEIM TO BE:

YOU, TI-IE SENDER (Your background and attitudes)

YOUR ABILITY TO SAAPE AND SEND MESSAGES OF YOUR MEANINGS

THE QUALITY OF THE MESSAGE (substance,

acceptability, form)

THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE MEDTIJM (Does it

facilitate or deter the message?)

THE ENVIRONMENT (external elements which help or block the message)

THE RECEIVER'S ABILITY TO RECEIVE

THE RECEIVER'S BACKGROUND AND ATTITUDES


SENDER AND RECEIVER BACKGROUND

Age Relationship to each other and potential ramifications

Attitude relationship to each other and potential

ramifications . Beneficial outcome; motives

Recent highlights of experience; uplifts, traumas,

sickness, diversions, etc.

Media preferences for physical or social appearance

Self-inage versus true or real inage Social attitudes, politics Insecurities and strengths

Specific knowledge of message area


SENDER AND RECEIVER ABILITIES (Skills in message sending)

Experience, practice, breadth or scope of

practice (Ever sent this message before?) Preferences related to training (you've got to like what you do)

Tools available, needed equipment Physical handicaps

Awareness; ability to relate to other interests

QUALITY OF THE MESSAGE

Is it perceivable

Is it relevant to the receiver, to society, to the time, etc.

Could it be misconstrued Is it too complex

Is its intention clear

Is it too long or too short

4

Does it balance other messages currently being sent

Can it survive noise factors

CHARACTERISTICS OF THE MEDIUM

Is it compatible to the situation; appropriateness Is it multi-sensory stimulating

Will it carry the message securely; does it allow the message to escape

Does it er,hance or distract from the message What are all the media choices; would another medium say it better

Is it intimate enough to allow the message to be personal

What are the 'symbolic' characteristics of

the medium

Does your receiver normally receive in this medium or will it be strange

Is the chosen medium a popular one

Does it block out interferences from environ- mental factors

Is it too obvious or too subtle Is it too fast or too slow

U

THE ENVIRO:JMENT (Factors which represent noise or distraction)

Is the environment complementary to the

message

Ternoerature (too warm)(too cool)

Vis l distraction (girl walks by, dog scratches fleas

Audible distraction (train passes by, chimes

ring)

Olfactory distraction (kitchen odors, etc.) Movement (any)

Appropriate time (too close to lunch, just after a night out, etc.)

Symtolic interference (prejudice against classrooms, etc.)

Wrong company (inappropriate audience grouping)

We could go on and on including more "rules of thumb" for helping us to better understand our world. We all need lots of such guidelines to more easily cope with our priorities involving love and learning, the use of our time, structure and order in the environment, the development of imagination and will-power and the ability to relax and concentrate.


Use these pages to begin your collection of travÂ­ el tips and travel guides which you believe have the potential for simplifying the journey to your goals.
